awd_titl_txt: L-Values, Special Cycles, and Euler Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Number theory, especially the study of properties of integers and rational numbers and the integer or rational solutions to equations, is one of the oldest branches of mathematics. It is also a meeting ground for many other branches of mathematics -- analysis, geometry, representation theory (to name a few) -- and progress on the fundamental problems in number theory continues to reveal surprising connections between these branches as well as new applications to other areas.  This project is focused on one of these fundamental problems and aims to establish new instances of these connections.

The fundamental problem at the heart of this project is to determine the arithmetic nature of the special values of L-functions of an algebraic variety or motive and to relate these values to the orders of algebraic quantities associated to the variety or motive (such as a Chow group, a class group, or a Selmer group).  An important and motivating instance is the celebrated Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture for elliptic curves, vastly generalized by the Bloch-Kato Conjectures.  This project will extend progress toward this fundamental problem through further development of connections between: L-functions, Galois representations, automorphic forms, representation theory, p-adic variation of L-values and modular forms, special cycles (especially on Shimura varieties), and special classes in Galois cohomology groups. This progress will unfold in two primary directions: (A) the proof of new instances of the Bloch-Kato Conjectures or their consequences (such as new cases of the p-part of the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer formula), and (B) the development of new tools and new methods for proving results towards these conjectures (such as new applications of representation theory to the existence Euler systems).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant was focused on a fundamental problem in algebraic number theory: understanding and proving the significance of special values of L-functions, especailly as reflected in the inspirational conjectures of Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer and of Bloch and Kato. 

Such L-functions are analytic functions of a complex variable s that are built from information attached to each prime number p (such as the number of points on an elliptic curve over the finite field of order p). However, values of the L-functions at special s are conjectured to encode other fundamental, but difficult to directly understand, information (such as the structure of the points over the rational numbers on an elliptic curve and of its Selmer group).

Results from the research supported by this project added significantly to the progress on these problems.

In the important and fundamental case of elliptic curves (the Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture or BSD Conjecture), this progress included:

1)  Proving (for the first time) that the conjectured BSD formula holds for an infinite number of elliptic curves of ranks zero and one. The 

2) Proving many new instance of the Iwaswa main conjectures for elliptic curves in many new cases and introducting new ways to link information gleaned from the different conjectures.

3) Proving a converse to the celebrated rank one case of the Gross-Zagier-Kolyvagin theorem.

4) Proving conjectures of Perrin-Riou and Kolyvagin about the refined structure of the Selmer group of an elliptic curve.

One of the most useful tools for studying the special values of L-functions are Euler systems -- when they are known to exist.  Since first being introduced in the 1980s, only a few examples have been found, although they are expected to exist in great generality. 

The research supported by this grant also produced new tools for constructing Euler system. This included:

5) Constructing the much-sought for Euler system for the adjoint of a modular form.

6) Definitng a new notion of an anticyclotomic Euler system, thereby extending Kolyvagin's fundamental work for elliptic curves to a vast range of L-functions.

7) Producing infintely many examples of new Euler systems as in (6), including the first example where the dimension of the underlying Galois representation can be arbitrarily large. 

During the period of this grant the PI had at least eight PhD students, five of whom completed their degrees during this time. Each was working on research partly supported by this grant. All of those that completed their degrees obtained post-doctoral positions.
